text: Hi, this is Julián from MinuteEarth.

The pandemic had some surprising effects on
our air quality.

As the world locked down, traffic and air
travel nearly ground to a halt, and many factories
shut down.

As a result, outdoor air quality improved:
five months in, the amount of particulate

matter and nitrogen dioxide dropped by 31%
and 60% globally.

But most of us weren't out and about in the
fresh-er air.

Thanks to remote working, learning, and socializing,
we've been at home - indoors - a lot more;
an average of 20% more early in the pandemic.

And while outside, nasty airborne stuff can
disperse and be carried away by wind or rain,

inside, it’s trapped - especially as we
build ever-more airtight homes for energy
efficiency.

As a result, pollutants can build up and they
are often 2 to 5 times more concentrated in

your living room than on the street right
outside.

Plus, while at home, we’ve been inadvertently
doing more of the things that release the

worst of these toxins, like cooking, which
we’ve been doing twice as much as we were
pre-pandemic.

Many of the fuels we cook with can release
dangerous gases or fine lung-coating particles,

sometimes at levels more than 100 times higher
than is considered safe.

And many cooking methods – even just burning
your food, which I count as a cooking method

– can release cancer-linked particles from
the food itself.

We’ve also been scrubbing down every scrubbable
surface in our homes with every cleaning product

we can find in an effort to keep our homes
virus-free.

But ironically, all this cleaning has made
our air dirtier.

That’s because some of the chemicals in
these products can react with other cleaning

products, dirty surfaces, or chemicals already
present in the air to produce some pretty
nasty pollutants.

For example, ozone in the air can break apart
the carbon-carbon bonds in some molecules
that make up the cleaning products.

The fragments then quickly combine with oxygen
or other compounds to form pollutants like
formaldehyde.

All this sounds pretty scary, especially when
you consider that, even before the pandemic-inspired

rise in cooking and cleaning, a study of air
quality in US homes found that in a worst

case-indoor-air scenario, the cancer risk
would be “unacceptable at US hazardous waste
sites.”
Yeesh.

Over the past few decades, we’ve become
more awair of the risks of indoor air pollution.

And the respiratory dangers posed by the COVID
pandemic may well be the push we need to make

long-overdue changes to our habits and the
places we inhabit, which should help us all
breathe a little easier.

Want an expert opinion on how to improve air
quality in your house?
We did too!

So I asked our sponsor Lydall, whose mission
is to create a cleaner, quieter and safer
world.

They recommend opening windows or doors to
bring in fresh air, using air purifiers with

HEPA filters, and putting a MERV 13 or higher
filter into your heating or air conditioning
system.

These filters trap microscopic particles,
including bacteria and many viruses.

Even pre-pandemic, I used them here in Montana
to trap ultrafine soot during fire season!

We’re glad to be sponsored by Lydall because
they’re one of the world’s only manufacturers

of filtration material for N95 and surgical
masks; last year, they supported the production
of nearly a billion face masks.

And now, they’re using their new Filtration
Center of Excellence to advance filtration

science to continuously improve standards
for air quality all around the world.
You can learn more at lydall.com.
From the top of our lungs, thanks Lydall!
